snippet: Syrian rebels have found an unlikely source for arms in Sudan, whose government sold the weapons to Qatar, which arranged delivery through Turkey, Western officials and the rebels said.
abstract: Syrian rebels, frustrated by the West’s reluctance to provide arms, have found an unlikely supplier in Sudan; Western officials and Syrian rebels say Sudan’s government sold weapons to Qatar, which arranged delivery to rebels through Turkey; Sudan has been under international arms embargoes and maintains close ties with a stalwart backer of the Syrian government, Iran.

byline.original: By C. J. CHIVERS and ERIC SCHMITT
byline.contributor: C. J. Chivers reported from Syria and the United States, and Eric Schmitt from Washington. Reporting was contributed by Andrew Kramer, Nikolai Khlalip and Andrew Roth from Moscow; Robert F. Worth from Washington; Sebnem Arsu from Istanbul; Nicholas Kulish from Nairobi, Kenya; Isma’il Kushkush from Khartoum, Sudan; and Karam Shoumali from Turkey and Syria.

lead_paragraph: Syrian rebels have found an unlikely source for arms in Sudan, whose government sold the weapons to Qatar, which arranged delivery through Turkey, Western officials and the rebels said.

headline.main: Arms Shipments Seen From Sudan to Syria Rebels
headline.print_headline: Arms Shipments Seen From Sudan To Syria Rebels
